III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not transport youth to the hospital when it was necessary.
Investigation The Complainant was contacted on 07/03/2024 and had no
additional information to provide.
Youth A was interviewed during an unannounced visit to her
school with DHHS Worker 1 on 06/12/2024. Youth A provided
recollections of instances when she needed medical attention at a
hospital and was refused that service by staff. She recalled an
instance that she could not date where she had back pain and a
staff that she could not recall refused to take her to the hospital.
She recalled being inside the house and because they refused to
take her, she walked out. Youth A recalled planning on walking to
the hospital. She stated that it did not take long for law
enforcement to ride up beside her. She told them she was
walking to the hospital, and she was not going back to the facility.
Youth A recalled talking with law enforcement for a little while on
the sidewalk and eventually they took her back to the facility.
Youth A stated she then went inside, sat down and waited for law
enforcement to leave, and then immediately left the facility to
AWOL again. Youth A stated this was when she found some
broken glass and cut her forearms with it. Youth A believed
facility staff had called law enforcement again after she walked out
the second time, and officers drove up next to her again. She
recalled being transported to the hospital by law enforcement at
that time. Youth A also recalled an incident where she AWOL’ed
from the house in a similar manner, but on this occasion, she
returned to the house on her own. She stated Staff 1 was present
as was law enforcement. When she arrived, she showed that she
had cut her forearm with some broken glass she had found.
Youth A expressed the need to go to the hospital at that time.
Youth A believed Staff 1 stated she did not need to go, only for the
2

law enforcement officer to take Youth A outside to speak with her.
She then reported the officer took Youth A to the hospital.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
06/17/2024. She stated there had been many incidents when she
had worked with Youth A and there was an instance of AWOL.
Staff 1 recalled the incident where Youth A left the facility and
AWOL’ed and law enforcement was called, only for Youth A to
arrive back at the facility shortly after law enforcement had also
reported to the facility. Staff 1 recalled Youth A talking directly
with law enforcement, and she remembered Youth A telling them
that she was triggered by Staff 1. She stated Youth A then
requested to call the Community Mental Health (CMH) crisis line
and Staff 1 assisted her in doing so. Staff 1 did not believe this
incident led to Youth A going to the hospital.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
06/17/2024. He stated he was not present at the facility during the
incident in question, despite being familiar with what occurred.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed over the phone with
DHHS Worker 1 on 06/17/2024. She recalled the incident in
question that occurred on 06/09/2024. The Chief Administrator
stated the largest part of Youth A’s escalation occurred when the
involved staff, of which she could not recall at that time, offered to
take her to Urgent Care to have attention given to her back pain.
This upset Youth A, who only wanted to go to the hospital. The
Chief Administrator believed that by the chance any other
discussion or offers or options took place Youth A escalated
further and left the facility.
During a video conference on 07/03/2034 DHHS Worker 1
provided an update on her investigation and was not able to state
a final result at that time.
Documentation reviewed:
• Multiple incident reports from the facility regarding AWOLs
for Youth A from June 2024. The documentation was
consistent with interviews provided.
• Documentation from local law enforcement dated
06/09/2024 was provided and reviewed. This
documentation described the instance of Youth A’s AWOL
and return to the facility shortly after law enforcement’s
arrival. The officer described arriving at the facility and
speaking with Staff 1. He stated Staff 1 did not know where
Youth A was and eventually requested she be listed as a
3

runaway. It was then that Youth A arrived back at the
facility. Youth A entered through the backdoor and law
enforcement spoke directly with her. Law enforcement
described the lacerations to her forearm and that she
expressed a need to go to the hospital. Youth A reported to
law enforcement that they were uncomfortable around Staff
1 and Staff 1 “treats her badly.” As Staff 1 was calling
facility management to discuss transporting Youth A to the
hospital, Youth A stated to law enforcement that she
“wanted to end it all” and law enforcement made the
decision to transport her to the hospital themselves.
• Facility policy titled “Health Services: Policies and
Procedures” and dated 01/14/2024 was reviewed. This
policy stated that for youth that had emergency care needs,
“an ambulance or transportation to the hospital would be
arranged.”
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that Youth A was denied proper medical attention during
any incidents described.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not providing medication to Youth A.
Investigation The Complainant was contacted on 07/03/2024 and had no
additional information to provide.
Youth A was interviewed during an unannounced visit to her
school with DHHS Worker 1 on 06/12/2024. Youth A reported
there was a recent occasion where Staff 1 would not provide her
medication. Youth A recalled Staff 1 asking her to go get a glass
of water so her medication could be provided. Youth A stated she
4

was busy doing something on the couch. Youth A believed the
next thing that occurred was Staff 1 told her “then I will mark you
down that you refused your medication.” Youth A recalled getting
up and getting a cup of water but at that time Staff 1 would not
give her medications out. Youth A clarified this was her nighttime
dosage of medication, and she was not sure if she went to bed
without her medication that night.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
06/17/2024. Staff 1 recalled the incident in question where Youth
A refused her medication. She stated she was working with Staff
2 that evening. Staff 1 requested Youth A get a glass of water to
take her medication, and Youth A then responded by stating “I’ll
get that when I feel like it.” Staff 1 explained to Youth A she had
to provide the medication now because she had already unlocked
the medication cabinet. Youth A told her she was going to take
her medication when she felt like it. Staff 1 recalled telling Youth
A she would have to document this as a medication refusal if that
was going to be Youth A’s choice. Staff 1 stated this was when
Youth A escalated, screaming and demanding to call the CMH
crisis phone line. When Staff 1 offered for Youth A to call the
facility therapist with which she worked with, Youth A continued to
escalate further. Staff 1 recalled contacting the License Designee
and she was instructed to call the CMH crisis line with Youth A.
Staff 1 recalled that before this could occur, Youth A left the facility
in an attempt to AWOL. Staff 1 stated Youth A was eventually
located by law enforcement and transported to the hospital.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
06/17/2024. Staff 2 stated he was often paired with Youth A for
the passing of her medication. He recalled many instances where
Youth A has refused to take her medication at the normal time it is
offered. Staff 2 could not recall a specific time of medication
passing similar to what was alleged by Youth A.
Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
07/03/2024. Staff 4 somewhat remembered the incident, recalling
Staff 1 asked Youth A to get ready to take her medications. Staff
4 believed Youth A did not respond in an agreeable manner, and
escalated to the point where she couldn’t be offered her
medications at that time. Staff 4 did not believe Staff 1 ever
refused to provide the medications to Youth A.
During a video conference on 07/03/2034 DHHS Worker 1
provided an update on her investigation and was not able to state
a final result at that time.
5

Documentation reviewed:
• Facility incident reports were provided and reviewed:
o Staff 1 authored an incident report dated 06/09/2024
describing the course of events of offering Youth A
her medication. The details in this documentation
were consistent with interviews provided.
o Staff 2 authored an incident report dated 06/09/2024
describing the course of events of Staff 1 offering
Youth A her medication. Staff 2 described Staff 1
offered the medication and when Youth A stated she
would get water to take it “when she felt like it.” Staff
2 stated Staff 1 gave Youth A some time before
continuing to attempt to provide the
medication. When Youth A came back and stated
she was then ready, Staff 1 was in the middle of
another task and stated she would get back to
passing the medication when she was able, and
Youth A escalated verbally and then physically from
there.
• Facility medication log documentation was provided and
reviewed. Youth A was prescribed two medications to take
in the evenings, and because she was in the hospital they
were not provided on location on the evening of
06/09/2024.
• Hospital documentation dated 06/09/2024 was reviewed.
This documented a mental health evaluation that was
provided to Youth A after she was brought to the hospital
by law enforcement. This document aligns with details in
the incident report and with interviews provided. This
documentation showed that Youth A received her evening
medications while at the hospital after they were initially
offered at the facility.
• Facility policy titled “Health Services: Policies and
Procedures” and dated 01/14/2024 was reviewed. The
facility utilizes two policy books for staff and for youth, but
there was no policy and procedure found describing what
staff are to do in an instance when a youth is refusing
medication.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that Youth A was not offered her medication as prescribed,
and the escalation in behavior and need for law enforcement and
medical professional involvement did not allow facility staff to
6

continue attempts to provide medication on the evening of
06/09/2024.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility is advised to increase the number of staff who
are trained to properly pass medications. This would
reduce the chances of youth missing their medications
because they are escalated at the time they are offered by
the currently available staff trained for this purpose.
• While incident reporting documentation for this incident was
sufficient, the facility is advised to revise their policies and
procedures that are intended to meet this rule to include
directions on what staff are to do when a youth is refusing
their medications.
Consultation provided:
• The facility is advised to continue assessing and looking to
improve staff training and support in rapport building and
verbal de-escalation with youth.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code Personal hygiene
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4148
Section (1) An institution shall assure that each resident maintains or
Description receives personal care, hygiene, and grooming appropriate to
the resident's age, sex, race, cultural background, and health
needs.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth was not provided necessary hygiene products.
Investigation During a face-to-face interview at her school with DHHS Worker 1
on 06/12/2024, Youth A reported there was an occasion the prior
day (06/11/2024) that staff at the facility did not provide her with
feminine hygiene product. When asked specifically which staff
refused to provide these to her, Youth A named Staff 2 as the staff
that did not provide those items to her. Youth A recalled getting
more upset after this, punching a wall next to the office and then
leaving the facility. Youth A stated law enforcement picked her up
outside and she eventually went to the hospital. She also noted
7

she received the needed hygiene items after returning from the
hospital and the morning of the interview.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
06/17/2024. He recalled the incident that occurred on 06/11/2024
involving Youth A and the need for hygiene products. He had
heard from other staff that Youth A needed hygiene products while
she was at school and staff purchased more of these items for
when she was back home from school. Staff 2 didn’t remember
this coming up until later in the evening when Youth A came
downstairs and asked for some of the items. Staff 2 recalled
Youth A escalating quickly and seemingly without reason, claiming
the hygiene items had been purchased would only be for her and
no other youth. Youth A was offered the hygiene items again by
he and Staff 6 and she refused. Youth A then escalated further,
punching walls and eventually encountering law enforcement and
being transported to the hospital.
Staff 5 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 over the phone on
07/03/2024. Staff 5 recalled being on staff on 06/11/2024 during
the incident in question. Staff 5 stated he did not interact directly
with Youth A during this, but he did witness Youth A request
needed hygiene products from Staff 2 and, as he described,
almost immediately she “got an attitude” and did not accept what
was offered to her. Staff 5 witnessed Staff 2 and Youth A looking
in the supply closet upstairs together during their interaction. Staff
5 saw Youth A then go downstairs in a “hissy fit.” He recalled
Staff 2’s reaction to Youth A as calm and appropriate.
Staff 6 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 over the phone on
07/03/2024. Staff 6 recalled Youth A asking to Staff 2 that she
needed a hygiene product. Because Staff 6 was assisting another
youth, Staff 2 went to provide this to Youth A. Staff 6 recalled
Staff 2 asking her for help to make sure the right product was
offered, and Staff 2 asked Youth A for a preference. Staff 6
recalled Youth A getting upset and stating she was only talking to
Staff 2, and not Staff 6. Staff 6 asked Staff 2 to take over the
interaction in order to assist Youth A in staying calm. Staff 6
recalled Youth A escalating from there, believing that she
eventually left the facility.
During a video conference on 07/03/2034 DHHS Worker 1
provided an update on her investigation and was not able to state
a final result at that time.
8

Documentation reviewed:
• Facility incident report documentation dated 06/11/2024
was reviewed. This document described an incident where
Youth A became upset at staff because she believed she
was being deprived of sanitary napkins that were meant
specifically for her. It was explained to Youth A the sanitary
napkins she referred to were for all the youth in the
program. Youth A’s behavior escalated to the point where
she was screaming and punching a wall. She did not
respond to offers to speak with the facility therapist, and the
behavior continued. Staff eventually called law
enforcement because of the property damage occurring.
Youth A then left the facility and went AWOL, and she was
located shortly thereafter and transported to the hospital for
evaluation.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that hygiene products for Youth A were withheld from her on
06/11/2024.
Consultation provided:
• Continued staff training regarding normal behaviors for
youth in this facility is needed. While it was clear that
Youth A escalated in a quick manner during this incident,
having it described as a “hissy fit” displays a lack of
understanding of the common struggles with emotional
intelligence and frustration tolerance for youth being served
by the facility.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited
to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
9

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth was allegedly restrained during an altercation with another
youth.
Investigation During a face-to-face interview at her school with DHHS Worker 1
on 06/12/2024, Youth A reported there was an occasion that staff
“went hands on” her, and she took issue with this because the
facility is not allowed to restrain youth. Youth A was not able to
further clarify what she meant by “hands on,” only repeating that
the youth at the facility are not supposed to be restrained and she
knew what this was like from past placements that did utilize
restraints. Youth A recalled getting into a physical altercation with
Youth C. Youth C was already outside in the front yard and Youth
A went out to meet her after Youth C asked her to in order to fight.
Youth A recalled Staff 2 and Staff 3 were present as well. Youth A
recalled both of the staff attempting to get in between the two
youth and prevent them from fighting. Youth A stated the physical
altercation between she and Youth C ended when Youth C hit
Youth A in the face, and then Youth A attempted to jump over the
fence of the facility to get away. Youth A could not specify how
the two staff members involved physically engaged with the youth
themselves other than to say that they attempted to get in
between Youth A and Youth C. Youth A showed a faint bruise on
her leg, and she stated she received it from the incident, but could
not specify how or from who.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 over the phone on
06/17/2024. She stated she witnessed the incident involving
Youth A and Youth C. She recalled staying in the house and
witnessing Youth A and Youth C trying to fight outside. Youth B
recalled seeing Staff 3 attempting to stop Youth A from getting
past her to fight Youth C. Youth B described Staff 3’s actions as
holding her hands out at either side and standing near Youth A
and facing her. Youth B did not state whether Staff 3 touched
Youth A in any way. She remembered the next thing that
happened was Youth A fell to the ground and Staff 3 fell on top of
her. Youth B recalled Staff 3 getting up quickly. Youth B believed
this fall for both individuals was accidental. Youth B stated she
did not see any more of the interaction.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 10/16/2024. She
recalled the incident in question. Staff 3 could not recall why
Youth A and Youth C were upset at each other, but she did recall
the altercation escalated significantly when Youth C was outside
10

and yelling to Youth A to come outside to fight her. Staff 3
recalled going outside with Staff 2 to address the youth. Staff 3
recalled going to Youth A, and she believed Staff 2 went to Youth
C. In doing so Staff 3 believed Youth C went around the other
side of the building outside and eventually ended up at the back
door to enter back inside. As that occurred, Staff 3 recalled Youth
A wanting to chase Youth C and fight her. Staff 3 stated she
attempted to stop this by standing in front of Youth A with her
arms out wide, blocking her path but taking care to not touch
Youth A. Staff 3 stated Youth A was standing with her back
against the fence in the front of the property, and Staff 3 stated
she had her own hands on the fence to try to block Youth A from
getting past her to attack Youth C. Staff 3 recalled she and Youth
A fell over and Staff 3 was on top of Youth A’s side. Staff 3 could
not recall exactly how this occurred, but she believed it was
caused by Youth A attempting to get past Staff 3. She recalled
they were on the ground for only a moment and Youth A was up
and going around the house, presumably to find Youth C. Staff 3
could not recall exactly how the situation was diffused but stated
there were no moments of hands on contact between anyone after
that point in time. Staff 3 was not injured during the incident and
believed Youth A experienced the same.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
06/17/2024. He recalled working the day that Youth A and Youth
C had a physical altercation. Youth C was already outside when
Youth A came out and wanted to fight her. Staff 2 recalled trying
to stay in between the two youth, and he believed Staff 3 was
doing the same. Staff 2 recalled ending up on the front porch with
Youth C, and Staff 3 was in the front yard near the fence with
Youth A. Staff 2 did not see any physical interaction between
Staff 3 and Youth A because he had followed Youth C around to
the back of the house. He stated law enforcement arrived shortly
thereafter and began to further de-escalate the situation.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed over the phone with
DHHS Worker 1 on 06/17/2024. She confirmed the location of
where Youth A and Staff 3 were outside is not covered by the
facility security cameras.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility incident report dated 06/04/2024 was provided and
reviewed. Details in this incident report were consistent
with interviews provided.
• Law enforcement documentation was provided and
reviewed. A police report dated 06/04/2024 described law
11

enforcement arrived on the scene after the instance of
alleged contact between Youth A and Staff 3 and detailed
alleged assaultive behavior between Youth A and Youth C.
• Facility policy titled “Interventions” last dated 01/14/2024
was reviewed, which stated that the use of physical
discipline inflicted in any manner was prohibited.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that Staff 3 performed a restraint, nor was there evidence
found that she struck Youth A in a prohibited manner.
Consultation provided:
• The facility is advised to continue to discuss and train on
physical contact with youth by staff. The facility has chosen
to not implement physical managements as a behavior
intervention and that is not in question, but escalated youth
can still present situations where physical contact occurs
and further debriefing on incidents such as this would be
beneficial for staff.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
